{
 "cells": [
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "# Setting things up\n",
    "\n",
    "## About this notebook\n",
    "\n",
    "In this notebook, we embark on a journey to elevate the predictive capabilities of the California Housing Prices Dataset through advanced preprocessing using the ``ContinuousCarver`` pipeline. Renowned for its association-maximizing discretization, ``ContinuousCarver`` is a powerful Python tool designed to handle diverse data types—whether they be quantitative or qualitative. Our specific goal is to prepare the dataset for continuous regression tasks, such as predicting housing prices.\n",
    "\n",
    "The California Housing Prices Dataset is a treasure trove of features, encompassing information on factors like square footage, bedrooms, location, and more. By employing ``ContinuousCarver``, we aim to seamlessly discretize both quantitative and qualitative features, tailoring them for optimal representation in our continuous regression models.\n",
    "\n",
    "Throughout this notebook, we'll explore the intricacies of ``ContinuousCarver``'s discretization pipeline, witnessing its adaptability to a variety of data types. Whether it involves transforming square footage or encoding location information, ``ContinuousCarver`` ensures that each feature is finely tuned for our regression tasks.\n",
    "\n",
    "Join us in this exploration as we leverage the power of ``ContinuousCarver`` to preprocess the California Housing Prices Dataset. Through effective feature engineering and discretization, our aim is to create a dataset that captures the nuanced relationships within the housing market, setting the stage for the development of accurate and impactful continuous regression models.\n",
    "\n",
    "Let's dive in and uncover the potential of ``ContinuousCarver`` in transforming the California Housing Prices Dataset for optimal predictive modeling.\n",
    "\n",
    "\n",
    "## Installation"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 1,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "# %pip install AutoCarver[jupyter]"
   ]

     ]

   "source": [
    "import sys\n",
    "import os\n",
    "\n",
    "print(os.listdir('../../../../../../AutoCarver'))\n",
    "\n",
    "sys.path.append('../../../../../../AutoCarver')\n",
    "sys.path.append('../../../../../../AutoCarver/AutoCarver')\n",
    "sys.path.append('../../../../../../AutoCarver/AutoCarver/discretizers')\n",
    "sys.path.append('../../../../../../AutoCarver/AutoCarver/discretizers/utils')\n",
    "import AutoCarver\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Califorinia Housing Prices Data\n",
    "\n",
    "In this example notebook, we will use the California Housing Prices dataset.\n",
    "\n",
    "The California Housing Prices dataset is a well-known dataset in the field of machine learning and statistics. It provides information about housing districts in California and is frequently used for regression analysis and predictive modeling tasks.\n",
    "\n",
    "Comprising housing-related metrics for various districts in California, such as median house value, median income, housing median age, average rooms, average bedrooms, population, households, and more, the California Housing Prices dataset is a valuable resource for exploring the relationships between different features and predicting the median house values (continuous regression)."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 3,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "text/html": [
       "<div>\n",
       "<style scoped>\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {\n",
       "        vertical-align: middle;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th {\n",
       "        vertical-align: top;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe thead th {\n",
       "        text-align: right;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "</style>\n",
       "<table border=\"1\" class=\"dataframe\">\n",
       "  <thead>\n",
       "    <tr style=\"text-align: right;\">\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th>MedInc</th>\n",
       "      <th>HouseAge</th>\n",

       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>4</th>\n",
       "      <td>3.8462</td>\n",
       "      <td>52.0</td>\n",
       "      <td>6.281853</td>\n",
       "      <td>1.081081</td>\n",
       "      <td>565.0</td>\n",
       "      <td>2.181467</td>\n",
       "      <td>37.85</td>\n",
       "      <td>-122.25</td>\n",
       "      <td>3.422</td>\n",

       "  </tbody>\n",
       "</table>\n",
       "</div>"
      ],
      "text/plain": [
       "   MedInc  HouseAge  AveRooms  AveBedrms  Population  AveOccup  Latitude  \\\n",
       "0  8.3252      41.0  6.984127   1.023810       322.0  2.555556     37.88   \n",
       "1  8.3014      21.0  6.238137   0.971880      2401.0  2.109842     37.86   \n",
       "2  7.2574      52.0  8.288136   1.073446       496.0  2.802260     37.85   \n",
       "3  5.6431      52.0  5.817352   1.073059       558.0  2.547945     37.85   \n",
       "4  3.8462      52.0  6.281853   1.081081       565.0  2.181467     37.85   \n",
       "\n",
       "   Longitude  MedHouseVal  \n",
       "0    -122.23        4.526  \n",
       "1    -122.22        3.585  \n",
       "2    -122.24        3.521  \n",
       "3    -122.25        3.413  \n",
       "4    -122.25        3.422  "
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 3,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "from sklearn import datasets\n",
    "\n",
    "# Load dataset directly from sklearn\n",
    "housing = datasets.fetch_california_housing(as_frame=True)\n",
    "\n",
    "# conversion to pandas\n",
    "housing_data = housing[\"data\"]\n",
    "housing_data[housing[\"target_names\"][0]] = housing[\"target\"]\n",
    "\n",
    "# Display the first few rows of the dataset\n",
    "housing_data.head()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Target type and Carver selection"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 4,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "text/plain": [
       "count    20640.000000\n",
       "mean         2.068558\n",
       "std          1.153956\n",
       "min          0.149990\n",
       "25%          1.196000\n",
       "50%          1.797000\n",
       "75%          2.647250\n",
       "max          5.000010\n",
       "Name: MedHouseVal, dtype: float64"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 4,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "target = \"MedHouseVal\"\n",
    "\n",
    "housing_data[target].describe()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "The target ``\"MedHouseVal\"`` is a continuous target of type ``float64`` used in a regression task. Hence we will use ``AutoCarver.ContinuousCarver`` and ``AutoCarver.selectors.RegressionSelector`` in following code blocks."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Data Sampling"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 5,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split\n",
    "\n",
    "# stratified sampling by target\n",
    "train_set, dev_set = train_test_split(housing_data, test_size=0.33, random_state=42)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 6,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [

       "      <td>2.377049</td>\n",

       "      <td>3.637</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>5617</th>\n",
       "      <td>3.5488</td>\n",
       "      <td>42.0</td>\n",
       "      <td>4.821577</td>\n",
       "      <td>1.095436</td>\n",
       "      <td>1044.0</td>\n",
       "      <td>4.331950</td>\n",

       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>20060</th>\n",

      ],
      "text/plain": [
       "       MedInc  HouseAge  AveRooms  AveBedrms  Population  AveOccup  Latitude  \\\n",
       "5088   0.9809      19.0  3.187726   1.129964       726.0  2.620939     33.98   \n",
       "17096  4.2232      33.0  6.189696   1.086651      1015.0  2.377049     37.46   \n",
       "5617   3.5488      42.0  4.821577   1.095436      1044.0  4.331950     33.79   \n",
       "20060  1.6469      24.0  4.274194   1.048387      1686.0  4.532258     35.87   \n",
       "895    3.9909      14.0  4.608303   1.089350      2738.0  2.471119     37.54   \n",
       "\n",
       "       Longitude  MedHouseVal  \n",
       "5088     -118.28        1.214  \n",
       "17096    -122.23        3.637  \n",
       "5617     -118.26        2.056  \n",
       "20060    -119.26        0.476  \n",
       "895      -121.96        2.360  "
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 7,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "train_set.head()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 8,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "text/plain": [
       "MedInc         float64\n",
       "HouseAge       float64\n",
       "AveRooms       float64\n",
       "AveBedrms      float64\n",
       "Population     float64\n",
       "AveOccup       float64\n",
       "Latitude       float64\n",
       "Longitude      float64\n",
       "MedHouseVal    float64\n",
       "dtype: object"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 8,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "# column data types\n",
    "train_set.dtypes"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "All features are quantitative continuous features at the exception of ``Latitude`` and ``Longitude`` which are geographical featues (not supported by ``AutoCarver`` as is). All other features will be added to the list of ``quantitative_features``."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 9,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "# lists of features per data type\n",
    "quantitative_features = [\"MedInc\", \"HouseAge\", \"AveRooms\", \"AveBedrms\", \"Population\", \"AveOccup\"]\n",
    "qualitative_features = []\n",
    "ordinal_features = []\n",
    "\n",
    "# user-specified ordering for ordinal features\n",
    "values_orders = {}"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "# Using AutoCarver"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## AutoCarver settings\n",
    "\n",
    "### Representativness of modalities\n",
    "\n",
    "The attribute ``min_freq`` allows one to choose the minimum frequency per basic modalities. It is used by **Discretizers**:\n",
    "\n",
    "- For quantitative features, it defines the number of quantiles to initialy discretize the features with.\n",
    "\n",
    "- For qualitative features, it defines the threshold under which a modality is grouped to either a default value or its closest modality."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 10,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "min_freq = 0.05"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "**Tip:** should be set between ``0.01`` (slower, preciser, less robust) and ``0.2`` (faster, more robust)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Desired number of modalities\n",
    "\n",
    "The attribute ``max_n_mod`` allows one to choose the maximum number of modalities per carved feature. It is used by **Carvers** has the upper limit of number of modalities per consecutive combination of modalities."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 11,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "max_n_mod = 5"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "**Tip:** should be set between ``3`` (faster, more robust) and ``7`` (slower, preciser, less robust)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Association metric\n",
    "\n",
    "The attribute ``sort_by`` allows one to choose the association metric used to sort combinations. Combinations of grouped modalities are ranked according to the specified modalities and the best ranked viable combination is returned by **Carvers**."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 12,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "# Optional for ContinuousCarver, the implemented metric is \"kruskal\"\n",
    "sort_by = \"kruskal\""
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Grouping NaNs\n",
    "\n",
    "The attribute ``dropna`` allows one to choose whether or not ``numpy.nan`` should be grouped with another modality. If set to ``True``, **Carvers** will first find the most suitable combination of non-NaN values, and then test out all possible combinations with ``numpy.nan``."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 13,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "dropna = False  # anyway, there are no numpy.nan in this dataset"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Optional attributes\n",
    "\n",
    "#### Minimal frequency per carved modality\n",
    "\n",
    "The attribute ``min_freq_mod`` allows one to choose the minimum frequency per output modality. It is used by **Carvers** in viability tests to put aside combinations that are not frequent enough in train or dev sets. By default, it is set to ``min_freq/2``."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 14,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "min_freq_mod = None  # for 0.05,  at least 5 % of observations per output modality in train and dev sets "
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "#### Type of output carved features\n",
    "\n",
    "The attribute ``output_dtype`` allows one to choose the output type:\n",
    "\n",
    "* Use ``\"float\"`` for integer output (default)\n",
    "* Use ``\"str\"`` for string output"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 15,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "output_dtype = \"float\"  # \"str\""
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Fitting AutoCarver\n",
    "\n",
    "* First, all quantitative features are discretized:\n",
    "    1. Using ``ContinuousDiscretizer`` for quantile discretization that keeps track of over-represented values (more frequent than ``min_freq=0.05``)\n",
    "    2. Using ``OrdinalDiscretizer`` for any remaining under-represented values (less frequent than ``min_freq/2=0.025``) to be grouped with its closest modality\n",
    "\n",
    "* Second, all features are carved following this recipe:\n",
    "    1. The raw distribution is printed out on provided ``train_set`` and ``dev_set``. It's the output of the discretization step\n",
    "    2. Grouping modalities: all consecutive combinations of modalities are applied to ``train_set``\n",
    "    3. Computing associations: the association metric (``sort_by=\"kruskal\"``) is computed with the provided target ``train_set[target]``\n",
    "    4. Combinations are sorted in descending order by association value\n",
    "    5. Testing robustness: finds the first combination that checks the following:\n",
    "        - Representativness of modalities on ``train_set`` and ``dev_set`` (all should be more frequent than ``min_freq_mod``)\n",
    "        - Distinct target rates per consecutive modalities on ``train_set`` and ``dev_set`` \n",
    "        - No inversion of target rates between ``train_set`` and ``dev_set`` (same ordering of modalities by target rate)\n",
    "    6. (Optional) If requested via ``dropna=True``, and if any, all combinations of modalities with ``numpy.nan`` are applied to ``train_set`` and steps 3. and 4. are run\n",
    "    7. The carved distribution is printed out on provided ``train_set`` and ``dev_set``. It's the output of the carving step"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 16,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",

      " - [OrdinalDiscretizer] Fit ['Population']\n",
      "------\n",
      "\n",
      "\n",
      "------\n",
      "[AutoCarver] Fit Population (1/1)\n",
      "---\n",
      "\n",
      " - [AutoCarver] Raw distribution\n"
     ]

     "name": "stdout",

     "text": [
      "------\n",
      "\n"
     ]
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "from AutoCarver import ContinuousCarver\n",
    "\n",
    "# intiating AutoCarver\n",
    "auto_carver = ContinuousCarver(\n",
    "    quantitative_features=quantitative_features,\n",
    "    qualitative_features=qualitative_features,\n",
    "    ordinal_features=ordinal_features,\n",
    "    values_orders=values_orders,\n",
    "    min_freq=min_freq,\n",
    "    min_freq_mod=min_freq_mod,\n",
    "    max_n_mod=max_n_mod,\n",
    "    dropna=dropna,\n",
    "    sort_by=sort_by,\n",
    "    output_dtype=output_dtype,\n",
    "    verbose=True,  # showing statistics\n",
    "    copy=True,  # whether or not to return a copy of the input dataset\n",
    ")\n",
    "\n",
    "# fitting on training sample, a dev sample can be specified to evaluate carving robustness\n",
    "train_set_processed = auto_carver.fit_transform(train_set, train_set[target], X_dev=dev_set, y_dev=dev_set[target])"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## AutoCarver analysis\n",
    "\n",
    "### Carving Summary"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 17,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "text/html": [
       "<div>\n",
       "<style scoped>\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {\n",
       "        vertical-align: middle;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th {\n",
       "        vertical-align: top;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe thead th {\n",
       "        text-align: right;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "</style>\n",
       "<table border=\"1\" class=\"dataframe\">\n",
       "  <thead>\n",
       "    <tr style=\"text-align: right;\">\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th>label</th>\n",
       "      <th>content</th>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>feature</th>\n",
       "      <th>dtype</th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "  </thead>\n",
       "  <tbody>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th rowspan=\"5\" valign=\"top\">Population</th>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>0</td>\n",
       "      <td>[x &lt;= 3.530e+02]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>1</td>\n",
       "      <td>[3.530e+02 &lt; x &lt;= 7.930e+02]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>2</td>\n",
       "      <td>[7.930e+02 &lt; x &lt;= 8.640e+02]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>3</td>\n",
       "      <td>[8.640e+02 &lt; x &lt;= 2.152e+03]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>4</td>\n",
       "      <td>[2.152e+03 &lt; x]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "  </tbody>\n",
       "</table>\n",
       "</div>"
      ],
      "text/plain": [
       "                  label                       content\n",
       "feature    dtype                                     \n",
       "Population float      0              [x <= 3.530e+02]\n",
       "           float      1  [3.530e+02 < x <= 7.930e+02]\n",
       "           float      2  [7.930e+02 < x <= 8.640e+02]\n",
       "           float      3  [8.640e+02 < x <= 2.152e+03]\n",
       "           float      4               [2.152e+03 < x]"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 17,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "auto_carver.summary()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "* As requested with ``output_dtype=\"float\"``, output labels are integers of ranks of modalities\n",
    "\n",
    "* For quantitative feature ``Population``, the selected combination of modalities groups populations as follows:\n",
    "    * modality ``0``: lower or equal to 353 people (``content==[\"x <= 3.530e+02\"]``)\n",
    "    * modality ``1``: greater than 353 people and lower or equal to 793 people  (``content==[\"3.530e+02 < x <= 7.930e+02\"]``)\n",
    "    * modality ``2``: greater than 793 people and lower or equal to 864 people (``content==[\"7.930e+02 < x <= 8.640e+02\"]``)\n",
    "    * modality ``3``: greater than 864 people and lower or equal to 2152 people (``content==[\"8.640e+02 < x <= 2.152e+03\"]``)\n",
    "    * modality ``4``: higher than 2152 people (``content==[\"2.152e+03 < x \"]``)\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Detailed overview of tested combinations"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 18,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [

       "47  [[x <= 3.530e+02], [3.530e+02 < x <= 5.140e+02...  28.839507      None   \n",
       "48  [[x <= 3.530e+02], [3.530e+02 < x <= 5.140e+02...  28.822334      None   \n",
       "49  [[x <= 3.530e+02], [3.530e+02 < x <= 5.140e+02...  28.795493      None   \n",
       "\n",
       "                                  viability_message  grouping_nan  \n",
       "0                              [Raw X distribution]         False  \n",
       "1   [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "2   [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "3   [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "4   [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "5   [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "6   [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "7   [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "8   [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "9   [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "10  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "11  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "12  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "13  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "14  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "15  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "16  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "17  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "18  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "19  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "20  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "21  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "22  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "23  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "24  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "25  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "26  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "27  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "28  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "29  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "30  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "31  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "32  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "33  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "34  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "35  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "36  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "37  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "38  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "39  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "40  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "41  [X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality]         False  \n",
       "42         [Combination robust between X and X_dev]         False  \n",
       "43                                    [Not checked]         False  \n",
       "44                                    [Not checked]         False  \n",
       "45                                    [Not checked]         False  \n",
       "46                                    [Not checked]         False  \n",
       "47                                    [Not checked]         False  \n",
       "48                                    [Not checked]         False  \n",
       "49                                    [Not checked]         False  "
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 18,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "auto_carver.history(\"Population\").head(50)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 19,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "text/plain": [
       "['X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality']"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 19,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "auto_carver.history(\"Population\")[\"viability_message\"][2]"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "* The most associated combination of feature ``Population`` (the first tested out, where ``viability_message!=[\"Raw X distribution\"]``) did not pass the viability tests. When looking in ``viability_message``:\n",
    "    * ``\"X_dev: inversion of target rates per modality\"``: target rates (mean values of ``MedHouseVal`` per grouped modality) are not ranked the same between ``train_set`` and ``dev_set``\n",
    "\n",
    "* For feature feature ``Population``, the 42nd combination is the first to pass the tests:\n",
    "    - ``viability_message!=[\"Combination robust between X and X_dev\"]``\n",
    "    - Kruskal-Wallis' H with ``MedHouseVal`` is ``29.050321`` for this combination\n",
    "    - Following combinations (less associated with the target) where not tested: ``viability_message==[\"Not checked\"]``\n",
    "\n",
    "* For all combinations ``grouping_nan==False`` means that it is not a combination in which NaNs are being groupedwith other modalities (as requested with ``dropna=False``)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Saving and Loading AutoCarver"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Saving\n",
    "\n",
    "All **Carvers** can safely be stored as a .json file."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 20,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "import json\n",
    "\n",
    "# storing as json file\n",
    "with open('continuous_carver.json', 'w') as my_carver_json:\n",
    "    json.dump(auto_carver.to_json(), my_carver_json)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Loading\n",
    "\n",
    "**Carvers** can safely be loaded from a .json file."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 21,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "import json\n",
    "\n",
    "from AutoCarver import load_carver\n",
    "\n",
    "# loading json file\n",
    "with open('continuous_carver.json', 'r') as my_carver_json:\n",
    "    auto_carver = load_carver(json.load(my_carver_json))"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Applying AutoCarver"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 22,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "dev_set_processed = auto_carver.transform(dev_set)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 23,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "text/html": [
       "<div>\n",
       "<style scoped>\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {\n",
       "        vertical-align: middle;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th {\n",
       "        vertical-align: top;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe thead th {\n",
       "        text-align: right;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "</style>\n",
       "<table border=\"1\" class=\"dataframe\">\n",
       "  <thead>\n",
       "    <tr style=\"text-align: right;\">\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th>Population</th>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>Population</th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "  </thead>\n",
       "  <tbody>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>3.0</th>\n",
       "      <td>0.539049</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>1.0</th>\n",
       "      <td>0.208749</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>4.0</th>\n",
       "      <td>0.150176</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>0.0</th>\n",
       "      <td>0.052995</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>2.0</th>\n",
       "      <td>0.049031</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "  </tbody>\n",
       "</table>\n",
       "</div>"
      ],
      "text/plain": [
       "            Population\n",
       "Population            \n",
       "3.0           0.539049\n",
       "1.0           0.208749\n",
       "4.0           0.150176\n",
       "0.0           0.052995\n",
       "2.0           0.049031"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 23,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "dev_set_processed[auto_carver.features].apply(lambda u: u.value_counts(dropna=False, normalize=True))"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "# Updating/Adjusting AutoCarver\n",
    "## Quantitative features: updating group thresholds\n",
    "\n",
    "Let's say one wants to adjust the values of a carved quantitative feature for better readability. Take feature ``\"Population\"`` for example, one could prefer group thresholds rounded to the nearest ten."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 24,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "Upper thresholds for groups of feature Population: [353.0, 793.0, 864.0, 2152.0, inf]\n"
     ]
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "feature = \"Population\"\n",
    "thresholds = auto_carver.values_orders[feature]\n",
    "print(f\"Upper thresholds for groups of feature {feature}: {thresholds}\")"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 25,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "text/html": [
       "<div>\n",
       "<style scoped>\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {\n",
       "        vertical-align: middle;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th {\n",
       "        vertical-align: top;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe thead th {\n",
       "        text-align: right;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "</style>\n",
       "<table border=\"1\" class=\"dataframe\">\n",
       "  <thead>\n",
       "    <tr style=\"text-align: right;\">\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th>label</th>\n",
       "      <th>content</th>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>feature</th>\n",
       "      <th>dtype</th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "  </thead>\n",
       "  <tbody>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th rowspan=\"5\" valign=\"top\">Population</th>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>0</td>\n",
       "      <td>[x &lt;= 3.500e+02]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>1</td>\n",
       "      <td>[3.500e+02 &lt; x &lt;= 7.900e+02]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>2</td>\n",
       "      <td>[7.900e+02 &lt; x &lt;= 8.600e+02]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>3</td>\n",
       "      <td>[8.600e+02 &lt; x &lt;= 2.150e+03]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>4</td>\n",
       "      <td>[2.150e+03 &lt; x]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "  </tbody>\n",
       "</table>\n",
       "</div>"
      ],
      "text/plain": [
       "                  label                       content\n",
       "feature    dtype                                     \n",
       "Population float      0              [x <= 3.500e+02]\n",
       "           float      1  [3.500e+02 < x <= 7.900e+02]\n",
       "           float      2  [7.900e+02 < x <= 8.600e+02]\n",
       "           float      3  [8.600e+02 < x <= 2.150e+03]\n",
       "           float      4               [2.150e+03 < x]"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 25,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "# grouping values into closest rounded hundred\n",
    "for threshold in thresholds[:-1]:  # be carefull not to round the np.inf and to keep it whatsoever\n",
    "    rounded_threshold = 10 * round(threshold / 10, 0)\n",
    "    auto_carver.update_discretizer(feature, \"replace\", threshold, rounded_threshold)\n",
    " \n",
    "auto_carver.summary(feature)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "Using ``ContinuousCarver.update_discretizer()`` we managed to round the thresholds of our groups. Be careful with changes to **Carvers** as no viability checks are performed."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Quantitative features: grouping built modalities\n",
    "\n",
    "Let's say one thinks there are to many modalities for carved feature ``\"Population\"``. Using ``ContinuousCarver.update_discretizer()`` we can easily group two existing groups."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 26,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "Upper thresholds for groups of feature Population: [350.0, 790.0, 860.0, 2150.0, inf]\n"
     ]
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "feature = \"Population\"\n",
    "thresholds = auto_carver.values_orders[feature]\n",
    "print(f\"Upper thresholds for groups of feature {feature}: {thresholds}\")"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "Threshold values ``790`` and ``860`` seem quite close compared to ``350`` and ``2150``. Let's group them:"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 27,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "text/html": [
       "<div>\n",
       "<style scoped>\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {\n",
       "        vertical-align: middle;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th {\n",
       "        vertical-align: top;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe thead th {\n",
       "        text-align: right;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "</style>\n",
       "<table border=\"1\" class=\"dataframe\">\n",
       "  <thead>\n",
       "    <tr style=\"text-align: right;\">\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th>label</th>\n",
       "      <th>content</th>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>feature</th>\n",
       "      <th>dtype</th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "  </thead>\n",
       "  <tbody>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th rowspan=\"4\" valign=\"top\">Population</th>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>0</td>\n",
       "      <td>[x &lt;= 3.500e+02]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>1</td>\n",
       "      <td>[3.500e+02 &lt; x &lt;= 8.600e+02]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>2</td>\n",
       "      <td>[8.600e+02 &lt; x &lt;= 2.150e+03]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>3</td>\n",
       "      <td>[2.150e+03 &lt; x]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "  </tbody>\n",
       "</table>\n",
       "</div>"
      ],
      "text/plain": [
       "                  label                       content\n",
       "feature    dtype                                     \n",
       "Population float      0              [x <= 3.500e+02]\n",
       "           float      1  [3.500e+02 < x <= 8.600e+02]\n",
       "           float      2  [8.600e+02 < x <= 2.150e+03]\n",
       "           float      3               [2.150e+03 < x]"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 27,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "auto_carver.update_discretizer(feature, \"group\", 790, 860)  # be careful to respect the real number ordering, otherwise labels and discretizations will be wrong\n",
    "auto_carver.summary(feature)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Quantitative features: adding new/unexpected modalities\n",
    "\n",
    "Let's say a new modality or missing values appear when using **Carvers** on new data. One can easily add these modalities to an existing group of its choice, once again, using ``ContinuousCarver.update_discretizer()``."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 28,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "Group thresholds for feature Population: [350.0, 860.0, 2150.0, inf]\n"
     ]
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "feature = \"Population\"\n",
    "thresholds = auto_carver.values_orders[feature]\n",
    "print(f\"Group thresholds for feature {feature}: {thresholds}\")"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "Let's add missing values ``nan`` to the highest group (upper threshold at ``inf``):"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 29,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "text/html": [
       "<div>\n",
       "<style scoped>\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {\n",
       "        vertical-align: middle;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th {\n",
       "        vertical-align: top;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe thead th {\n",
       "        text-align: right;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "</style>\n",
       "<table border=\"1\" class=\"dataframe\">\n",
       "  <thead>\n",
       "    <tr style=\"text-align: right;\">\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th>label</th>\n",
       "      <th>content</th>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>feature</th>\n",
       "      <th>dtype</th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "  </thead>\n",
       "  <tbody>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th rowspan=\"4\" valign=\"top\">Population</th>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>0</td>\n",
       "      <td>[x &lt;= 3.500e+02]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>1</td>\n",
       "      <td>[3.500e+02 &lt; x &lt;= 8.600e+02]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>2</td>\n",
       "      <td>[8.600e+02 &lt; x &lt;= 2.150e+03]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>float</th>\n",
       "      <td>3</td>\n",
       "      <td>[2.150e+03 &lt; x, __NAN__]</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "  </tbody>\n",
       "</table>\n",
       "</div>"
      ],
      "text/plain": [
       "                  label                       content\n",
       "feature    dtype                                     \n",
       "Population float      0              [x <= 3.500e+02]\n",
       "           float      1  [3.500e+02 < x <= 8.600e+02]\n",
       "           float      2  [8.600e+02 < x <= 2.150e+03]\n",
       "           float      3      [2.150e+03 < x, __NAN__]"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 29,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "from numpy import nan, inf\n",
    "\n",
    "auto_carver.update_discretizer(feature, \"group\", nan, inf)  # be careful to respect the real number ordering, otherwise labels and discretizations will be wrong\n",
    "auto_carver.summary(feature)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "``nan`` has been added to the highest modality has the default missing value in **Carvers** (``str_nan=\"__NAN__\"``). For the sake of the example, we will simulate some randomly missing values in the feature and apply the ``ContinuousCarver`` discretization:"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 30,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "# inserting missing values\n",
    "dev_set_with_nan = dev_set.copy()\n",
    "dev_set_with_nan.loc[dev_set_with_nan.sample(frac=0.1).index, feature] = nan"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 31,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "# processing datasets\n",
    "dev_set_processed = auto_carver.transform(dev_set)\n",
    "dev_set_with_nan_processed = auto_carver.transform(dev_set_with_nan)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 32,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "Distribution of Population that has no missing values (raw dev_set)\n",
      " Population\n",
      "0.0    0.052554\n",
      "1.0    0.254844\n",
      "2.0    0.542278\n",
      "3.0    0.150323\n",
      "Name: proportion, dtype: float64\n",
      "Distribution of Population that has missing values (dev_set_with_nan)\n",
      " Population\n",
      "0.0    0.046976\n",
      "1.0    0.231797\n",
      "2.0    0.485026\n",
      "3.0    0.236201\n",
      "Name: proportion, dtype: float64\n"
     ]
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "print(\"Distribution of Population that has no missing values (raw dev_set)\\n\", dev_set_processed[feature].value_counts(dropna=False, normalize=True).sort_index())\n",
    "print(\"Distribution of Population that has missing values (dev_set_with_nan)\\n\", dev_set_with_nan_processed[feature].value_counts(dropna=False, normalize=True).sort_index())"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "As requested, the missing values have been grouped with the modality labeled ``3``!"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "# Feature Selection\n",
    "## Selectors settings"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Features to select from\n",
    "\n",
    "Here all features have been carved using ``ContinuousCarver``, hence all features are qualitative."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 33,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "features = qualitative_features + quantitative_features + ordinal_features"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "\n",
    "### Number of features to select\n",
    "\n",
    "The attribute ``n_best`` allows one to choose the number of features to be selected per data type (quantitative and qualitative)."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 34,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "n_best = 6  # here the number of features is low, ClassificationSelector will only be used to compute useful statistics"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Using Selectors"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 36,

       "      <td id=\"T_14e69_row5_col0\" class=\"data row5 col0\" >float64</td>\n",
       "      <td id=\"T_14e69_row5_col1\" class=\"data row5 col1\" >0.0000</td>\n",
       "      <td id=\"T_14e69_row5_col2\" class=\"data row5 col2\" >0.5498</td>\n",
       "      <td id=\"T_14e69_row5_col3\" class=\"data row5 col3\" >3.0000</td>\n",
       "      <td id=\"T_14e69_row5_col4\" class=\"data row5 col4\" >29.0503</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "  </tbody>\n",
       "</table>\n"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    },
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "\n",
      " - [Selector] Selected qualitative features: ['AveRooms', 'AveOccup', 'MedInc', 'AveBedrms', 'HouseAge', 'Population']\n",
      "------\n",
      "\n"
     ]
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "from AutoCarver.selectors import RegressionSelector\n",
    "\n",
    "# select the most target associated qualitative features\n",
    "feature_selector = RegressionSelector(\n",
    "    qualitative_features=features,\n",
    "    n_best=n_best,\n",
    "    verbose=True,  # displays statistics\n",
    ")\n",
    "best_features = feature_selector.select(train_set_processed, train_set_processed[target])"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "* Feature ``MedInc`` is the most associated with the target ``MedHouseVal``:\n",
    "    - Kruskal-Wallis' H value is ``kruskal_measure=6207.67678``\n",
    "    - It has 0 % of NaNs (``pct_nan=0.0``) \n",
    "    - Its mode, ``0``, represents 25 % of observed data (``pct_nan=0.2500``)\n",
    "\n",
    "* Here, no feature where filtered out for there inter-feature association or over-represented values (no thresholds were set)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## What's next?\n",
    "\n",
    "* Thanks to **Carvers** all of your features are now optimally processed for your regression task!\n",
    "* As a final step towards your model, **Selectors** can prove to be handy tools to operate target optimal Data Pre-Selection, so make sure to check out [Selectors Examples](https://autocarver.readthedocs.io/en/latest/selectors_examples.html)!\n",
    "\n",
    "## Well done!\n",
    "\n",
    "Your commitment to achieving optimal results in continuous regression tasks shines through in your meticulous use of **AutoCarver**'s ``ContinuousCarver`` for data preprocessing. By fine-tuning and optimizing your dataset, you have set the stage for robust and accurate machine learning models.\n",
    "\n",
    "The ``ContinuousCarver`` has proven to be a valuable ally in your pursuit of excellence, carving out a path toward enhanced feature representation and model interpretability. Your dedication to refining the data preprocessing steps reflects a commitment to extracting the maximum value from your datasets.\n",
    "\n",
    "We extend our sincere appreciation for choosing **AutoCarver** as your companion in the data preprocessing journey. Your use of **AutoCarver** demonstrates a dedication to leveraging cutting-edge tools for achieving excellence in continuous regression tasks.\n",
    "\n",
    "As you transition to the modeling phase, may the carefully crafted features and preprocessing steps contribute to the success of your predictive models. We're excited to see the impact of your work and are grateful for the opportunity to be part of your data science endeavors.\n",
    "\n",
    "Thank you for trusting **AutoCarver**, and we wish you continued success in your data-driven ventures."
   ]
  }
 ],
 "metadata": {
  "kernelspec": {
   "display_name": "py39",
   "language": "python",

  },

   "codemirror_mode": {
    "name": "ipython",

   },
